turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about National Enquirer.
turn.1: What was the National Enquirer's legacy?
turn.2: In the late 1950s and through most of the 1960s, the publication was known for its gory and unsettling headlines and stories such as: "I Cut Out Her Heart and Stomped on It" (September 8, 1963) and "Mom Boiled Her Baby and Ate Her" (1962).
turn.4: At this time the paper was sold on newsstands and in drugstores only.
turn.6: Pope stated he got the idea for the format and these gory stories from seeing people congregate around auto accidents.
turn.7: Did many people read the paper?
turn.8: By 1966, circulation had risen to one million.
turn.9: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.10: Pope pioneered the idea of selling magazines at supermarket checkouts.
turn.11: What did the supermarkets say about the idea?
turn.12: In order to get into the supermarkets, Pope completely changed the format of the paper in late 1967 by dropping all the gore and violence and instead focusing on more benign topics like celebrities, the occult and UFOs.
